title: Thinking through Uncertainty: Nonconsequential Reasoning and Choice

steps: Subjects played a series of 40 one-shot games, including Prisoner's Dilemma (PD) games against different opponents.
PD games were presented in triads consisting of three versions: opponent strategy unknown, opponent known to have competed, and opponent known to have cooperated.
PD games were interspersed with other two-person games to prevent the development of standard strategies.
Subjects participated in a version of Newcomb's problem involving two boxes (A and B) and a computer program that predicted their choice with 92% success.
Subjects chose between taking both Box A and Box B or taking only Box B.
A separate group of subjects played PD games and were offered the opportunity to pay a small fee to learn the opponent's decision before making their own choice.
